ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about a wide range of performance art styles and techniques as well as how to implement those in a low stakes, high reward environment.
Performance art in theory and practice (through engaging with reading materials and self-directed experimentations)

This course taught me so much! On a basic level, I learned a lot about the history and practice of performance art. I learned a lot about myself as a performer and artist. I learned (or rather, remembered) that there are so many ways to process and respond to informationI found our weekly performance responses to be incredibly generative. Perhaps most importantly, I learned what a truly community-oriented class felt like. This class expanded the possibilities of what a Yale course could be! I learned a lot about creating / being in community with others, and about what collaboration and mutual support can look like in an art space.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was one of my favorite that I've taken at Yale in that I never felt like I was being forced to do anything. Everything we did felt like it was on our own terms and like we were able to choose our level of work so long as we were honest and engaged. It was extremely refreshing and a lot of fun to meet each week in this way.

The community-oriented nature of the course is the primary strength of the coursethe trust, warmth, and support that we fostered together was the reason that I think we all felt able to share and be vulnerable as we were. The performance response structure was also a major strength of the courseI loved that we could respond to our readings that way. And the readings were really fantastic! So much food for thought. 

I wish that the syllabus could be a little less white and a bit more well-rounded in terms of the performers it centers (more POC and queer folks). I understand that historically, "Performance Art" was very white for a long time, and the syllabus is the way it is because this class seeks to provide a background in the history of the practice. That said, I wonder if there could be creative ways of incorporating the work of more contemporary and diverse artists as well.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I felt that the hybrid model worked incredibly well this semester. I felt so energized by our in person seminars.

I thought the part-virtual, part-in-person structure worked really wellI can't imagine taking this class completely virtually, and I'm really glad that we had the opportunity to be in a room together (safely) each week. Obviously, I would have loved to have discussion in-person as well, but given the circumstances it was the best case scenario. 

Having Anisa on zoom all the time was difficult in the sense that it sometimes made me feel less present in the space, and having a phone held up was sometimes disruptive to performances. Ideally, everyone would be able to come in person for a class that involves live sharing and bodies in space. That said, it was obviously all worthwhile to have Anisa there, and totally necessary given the circumstances!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. This class feels like a performance lab. Shilarna and Anisa are so kind and thoughtful. It is simply a joy to be with them every week. Also, I found that this course attracted a particularly unique and diverse group of students. The structure of the course allowed for me to get to know them and I truly feel like I have a new group of interesting friends.
Yes! What a wonderful class with a wonderful professor! The class prompted a lot of creative thought, collaboration, empathy, and care!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Both in person performances and zoom discussions
half virtual seminar, half in-person seminar.
